3) Cut something

Battery holder designed to fit a 49mm wide battery like a Multistar 5200 4S. I use velco in the belly of the firstar then this mount also has velcro on it. A battery strap is used to secure the battery to this mount. The battery is secured to the mount outside the model, then it's all placed inside and adjusted for CG if needed.

I have removed the internal mount in the front of the plane.

I might improve this in the future.

New thumb sticks for the hubsan remote.
Feel much nicer to the fingers than the original ones

After buying a Moto Guzzi V7 i wanted to make a model of a 90°-V2-engine.
So here it is the Version 1.0 next version will also have cylinderheads, valves and a camshaft.
But this will take more effort and time than this simple model.
Nevertheless its a beautiful model and i did not see anything comparable on Thingiverse sofar.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

l3

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Printing:
Print two times Conrod1/2, Cylinder, Piston, Piston bold
The rest has only to be printed once.
I printed it with my Prusa l3, support is only needet at crankshaft1 and the Cylinders.

Assembly

Stick both parts of the crankshaft in the housing it will fit without glue, put the crank on the right side.

Then glue the cylinders on the housing make sure that the holes align well.
now put the piston bold through the first hole in the piston, put it through the conrod then in the second hole of the piston. You might need a hammer.

Start pushing the first piston through the cylinder and glue the second conrod part on the other side make sure you don´t glue it on the crankshaft.

After the glue is dried you can lube it a bit with siliconspray.

Ideas and critic in the comment section would be nice.
I designed it using Catia V5 which i can use at my university

/****29 JUNE LONG OVERDUE UPDATE:/
shit so I've been quite busy with other projects, I'm putting this on hold but giving whoever wants the STEP files to work on this.
I'm using fusion360, if anyone would like different export versions, do let me know. This is the first time exporting a file so it might not turn out so good.

FATAL ERROR WITH DESIGN: The gearing slows down the fan rather than speed it up.

If anything just drop me a comment and I'll address it.

/*****/

Project in the works, uploading so people can look at it, maybe take it further.

The idea behind it is a laminar flow fan to be mounted OUTSIDE your 3d printer, at the printer head level.

This hopefully should give a good laminar flow of air, cooling the filament soon after it exits the nozzle, resulting in delightful 3D prints that you and your generations to come can look at and marvel.

This is just the housing, the mount for the motor and the coupling between my gear, ball bearing and shaft.

I'll upload a new file soon incorporating all of these together.

This is a unibody FPV replacement frame for the Blade 200 QX. It's designed to work with the RunCam ring mount I've also uploaded if you're going to set it up for FPV. It has room under the body for the stock electronics, and room for a VTX at the rear end (I'm using a 200mW unit). I printed the prototype using PLA and it seems pretty strong, no issues with it yet - but this is also a work in progress.

The pictures are of the previous version. The latest version has the following added:

  • front and rear slots in frame
  • slots by the motor have been expanded to allow the connectors through
  • the square side frame cut-outs have been updated to a triangular pattern
  • posts were added to the main body to allow screwing in the bottom frame, which is now included and pre-drilled

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:739573

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=739573

Using the following options:

font_outline_width = 0.5
barextruder = extruder1
bar_color = Khaki
outline_color = Gray
lug_text_distance = 2
font_with_style =
bar_length_trim = 0
font_size = 12
border_color = Black
outline_thickness = 3.0
whichextruder = monochrome
textextruder = extruder2
line_spacing = 1.4
outlineextruder = extruder1
borderextruder = extruder2
lug_style = plate
inner_margin_width = 1.5
font_weight = 0
ruler_unit = 10
line5 =
line4 =
line3 =
line2 =
line1 = Sabrina T
border_width = 1.2
bar_style = surround_text
text_color = DarkRed
character_spacing = 1
lug_width = 6
glyph_coalesce = 25
bar_thickness = 2.4
glyph_coalesce_strategy = bar and glyphs
font_name = Aladin
border_thickness = 3.6
text_thickness = 4.2
outer_margin_width = 1
minimal_color_layer_thickness = 0.6
writing_direction = ltr
lug_length = 4
font_narrow_widen = 0
bar_shift = 0
font_outline_style = rounded
bar_width = 5

UPDATED: 04/30/2014 Added bold=
(be sure to download the latest version of write.scad to use this feature)
bold=0 (not bold) bold=1(bolder by 10%) bold=2 (bolder by 20%) etc.. (fractions work too) Thanks MichaelAtOz for minkowski tip :)
examples
write("Hello world",bold=1)
or
writesphere("Hello World",[15,15,15],12,bold=.5); UPDATED: 04/24/2013 M_G pointed out that space didn't work properly on writecube.. (fixed) Thanks M_G!!
UPDATED: 03/06/2013 Added Help file for creating fonts.
I have looked everywhere for an easy way to write on my 3d objects. Everything I could find was hard to manipulate, so I decided to give it a shot myself. Hope you like this as much as I do. I'll try to answer any questions you have. write.scad Routines:
write()
writecube()
writesphere()
writecylinder()
writecircle() Fonts:
letters.dxf (change in write.scad)
orbitron.dxf
braille.dxf
knewave.dxf
BlackRose.dxf
writecylinder specs in testwritecylinder.scad
Be glad to add more fonts if requested, or give details to make your own.

=================================================================
You are welcome to use and distribute this code freely. no need to make it a derivative of write.scad Check back every once in a while for additions. If you make something really cool that uses it, let me know. I want to see :) HAVE FUN WITH IT, and comments are always appreciated.

comments.text:
To new Linux users: This script won't work 'out of the box' as Linux file naming (which OpenSCAD follows) is case sensitive. Therefore to use/include it, you will have to either rename the file Write.scad to write.scad, or change all the use/include statements to Write.scad. Until you do this you will get an error: "WARNING: Can't open 'use' file 'write.scad'."
Otherwise an awesome script!

description.text:
This is a multilayer "sandwich" quadcopter, 180 sized, greatly inspired from Sigan 180 and bauerman design.

Follow me on twitter & facebook to see my other design progress :

  • https://twitter.com/hicwic

  • https://www.facebook.com/hicwicen

  • Designed to be easily printed, with no supports needed. Fit on a 200x200 printer bed.
  • It's made to fit 1806 or 1804 motors (M2 motor screw hole) and 4 inch props.
  • Camera support is made to be sandwiched with 30mm spacers between top and hat part. 3 mount angles available 0, 15, 30 degree.

BUILD INSTRUCTIONS
Part list :

  • 8x M3x8 screws
  • 16x M3x6 screws
  • 4x 30mm spacers (alu or nylon)

1- Screw the bottom plate to the spacer from downside with M3x8 screws, directly in plastic. DO NOT overthight !
2- Screw the 30mm spacers to top plate from inner side.
3- Install electronics components
4- Screw top plate to spacer from upperside, directly in plastic with M3x6 screws. DO NOT overthight !
5- Screw Hat to 30mm spacers with M3x6 screws.

UPDATE 28/06/16 - 12h08 added a new top in remixes with buzzer holder and battery delimiter

UPDATE 17/06/16 - 00h10 replaced spacer v7

  • Sightly bigger hole for fpv antenna & renforcement around fpv antenna hole
  • Added facebook address for followers

UPDATE 11/06/16 - 23h50 replaced Top v9.

  • Reduce motor main hole to fit 1804-1806 perfectly
  • Added a version with extended XT60 holder.
  • Added some build instructions

UPDATE 10/06/16 - 22h12 replaced Hat v6, Top v6 and camera support V4

  • Correct a problem in front screws position. Those version are deprecated.

Feedbacks are welcome.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

15-20%

description.text:
This remix accommodates the Australian Lybina Brand, which typically uses spools 165mm in diameter x 100mm wide. This accommodates two 608 bearings at each point. If you are having trouble with your bearings rotating, oil their surface so the filament can just slide on the metal.  
edit: Increased base support, added 1 mil bearing spacers and lowered the hole to fence the filament from sliding off.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hWc4VNt0GtG

I had to run 6 speaker cables, a cable tv coaxial line, and a network cable on the surface of a wall in the garage as there was no way to conceal it inside that particular wall. All 8 cables were roughly the same size so I made a wall mounting clip to keep the wires nice straight and organized. I could have purchased big wire concealers or made a box/duct to conceal the wires but I figured in the garage this is an acceptable more industrial look anyway.

The holes that hold the cables are 7mm and that worked for my coax cable, ethernet cable, and 14AWG 2-wire, in-wall rated speaker wire. If your wires are a bit different in size you may be able to scale it slightly. If they are way different I may be able to find time to resize them for you if you send me a message and I can post it.

comments.text: Wouldn't conduit or wall duct look nicer?
comments.author: ritzy

comments.text: Had wall duct on it when it wasn't so many wires but I would have needed a bigger size to fit all the new wires and since it was the garage I liked how this looked just as much as buying larger duct and slapping it on the wall. But its all preference, and obviously this isn't for everyone.

remixed_from.author: technomastermind
remixed_from.title: (minion) ramps 1.4 for mostly printed cnc multitool

description.text:
A slightly remixed version of the Minion Body Remix by glmoulton (which was a remix of the Minion Ramps 1.4 for mostly printed cnc multitool by technomastermind).

I've built on what glmoulton did (added extra holes for split loom cable entry and adapted the mounting for v-slot) by removing the 2 x 40mm rear fan mounts and putting a single 60mm on the top of the ramps portion (as per spauda01's ramps enclosure which is what I based the fan grille on). I have also put air intake slots in the rear where the 2 x 40mm fans originally mounted.

The fan can be secured with M3 screws and suitable nuts.

Just something I made for my own build as I already had a 60mm fan, thought I'd share in case it's of any use to anyone. You will need to check you have enough clearance above your ramps board to fit in the fan (and are generally happy that it will fit your components), and also print the remainder of the parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1029926

comments.text: I think without even knowing it you fixed another problem with the other design, no vents for the air to exit so the device can be properly cooled. CFM in cannot exceed CFM out so putting two fans on the other design was really pointless. Here's another thing most amatuer designers don't understand, as long as you have adequate intake/outlet vents then you are really better off having the fan blow out and sucking the cool air in through the sides and over the heatsinks then UP and out of the enclosure .... Heat rises and blowing the heat rising off the heatsinks back onto the chip and PCB is working against your main goal, pulling heat AWAY from the IC and heatsink. One of the few exceptions to this rules is modern CPUs but they are made completely different from common small ICs and a lot of people falsely believe that's the correct way to cool everything but it's simply not true. To keep things from falling inside and also act as a dust filter take a piece of speaker grille cloth, stretch and glue it to the inside of the enclosure, just remember to take a vac and suck the dust off every so often. Speaker cloth is loosely woven and 'acoustically transparent' which means it also passes air pretty well (Until it get plugged up with dust)
comments.author: longjohn119

comments.text: Very nicely done.

title: Voronoi Alphabet (Complete from A to Z!!)

description.text:
Complete Alphabet in Voronoi style. I made a separate file for each char, so print what you need and mix up materials, colors and chars for some super awesome signage power!  
Please leave a message or a heart if you like these parts.. hope you have some good use for them ;-)

The printing of these characters on an FDM Machine is very possible, but you will have to experiment with the angle, brim, support setting of your slicer to optimize each character.
I use:
0% infill
support from buildplatform
2 perimeter lines
0.1 - 0.2mm layer height
Slow speed printing -> 40mm/s

description.text: BARANDA PARA ESCALERA PEQUEÑA DE EXIN CASTILLOS

There are many building and structures on Thingiverse.com. But, I haven't really seen anyone who has been converting or making 3D rendered sections of say Dungeon and Dragon game maps. So, as a doodle, I made a 100 by 100 mm section using a 1 sq cm grid as the step size. Thought this might start a trend with some of the artsie types maybe pitching in to build a mix and match kind of grab bag of map sections. Think of it as Legos for Role Playing. If it's been done already, I sorry I didn't find such. :-) Oh, I doubt the sketchup file will print as is. I didn't follow their "rules" when adding the partial roof to the structure. If you remove the roof, it will print fine. Which is probably for the best anyway because the roof would most likely need to be a seperate piece for the gaming world. Have a great day,
Bill.

description.text: I really liked Reconnnn's Pebble Classic charging stand but thought some improvements could be made. A few tweaks were needed to make the charger plug and cord fit nicely. I also extended the lower platform so you can just set down the watch in the "corner" and have it connect with the magnetic connector with confidence. Additional structure was added to reinforce the strength of the overall unit, greatly increasing its likelihood of surviving a floor impact. I also made some shape decisions so the unit can be printed with zero support. (a brim might still be a good idea depending on your printer). Now that I have made this unit I can now plop my Pebble in easily and with confidence, knowing I can get it charging easily. ( Check out this short video to see what I mean. https://youtu.be/yf6E3xI5jsU ) I know this unit isn't for Pebble's latest and greatest models, but as of this writing a new one is only $99 and good used ones can be found on ebay for ~$50. (Great value - much better than iWatches or any other smart watch I know about). Share and Enjoy!!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Custom modified Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I like printing this with .2mm layers.

This is a remix so I started with the source STL file and imported it into Blender and started tweaking. I highly recommend getting a 3DConnexion space-mouse, which I love using in Blender. One hand moves my "head around" and I manipulate things with the other. It makes for fast and pleasant editing. After I get my design right, I export it to another STL file and usually clean it up with Netfabb-Free that can automatically make minor repairs and help me make sure the design is manifold. I then slice the product using Repetier host with the Cura slicer and upload the gcode to my 3d printer that is running Octoprint on a Raspberry Pi that drives the Arduino syetem of the printer. Then the plastic takes form. :-)

A while back, I got a cheap caliper from harbor freight, and after a while, there was a little piece of foam that came undone from the rest. It is at the bottom right of the caliper place, like there was a placeholder there or something, and since Ive been using it to design hotend parts and such, I designed this.  
Just print it out and slip it into the spot where that little shape of foam isnt really attached in that well, or might be missing by now if youve had the calipers for a while. There is the files for freecad so that you can make any size or shapes that you need for your holders. You can also extrude the piece upwards so there's a lip and design a lid using the same design also, but everything holds fine for me, so I dont really bother with it.

title: Parametric Azteeg X3 Mount for Arduino Mega/RAMPS holes

description.text: This is designed to allow the mounting of an Azteeg X3 into the holes for an Arduino Mega on an Ord Bot plate. It has extra space under for running wire under the board because it takes up the space that is provided  above and below. It also has mounts to assist in securing the wiring down.

This was made in OpenSCAD. The OpenSCAD files are available for download. You can adjust all sorts of variables if you have different screws want more or less space below the board or whatever you like. I have not successfully printed this yet, but I think that has more to do with my printer's capability than it does with the model. If you have some suggestions for improvements of the model's features, the OpenSCAD code or settings for best printing please leave a comment. Here are the settings available and their defaults
// General
standoff_wall_thickness = 3; // How thick should the walls of the radius be?
height_base = 2; // How high should the base of that connects everything together be? // Arduino Mega Specific
standoff_inner_radius_am = 1; // How big a hole should be in the middle of the standoff?
height_am = 3; // How tall should the Arduino Mega standoffs be? // X3 Specific
standoff_inner_radius_x3 = 3; // How big a hole should be in the middle of the standoff? (X3 hole is about 3.8)
height_x3 = 15; // How tall should the X3 standoffs be? // Settings for the cable tie mounts
height = 7;
width = 10;
depth = 5;
wall_width = 3;

comments.text: I upgraded the files to hopefully help the customizer's variables be a bit more clear. I also included a version that does not have the cable tie holders.

"The A340-500 was introduced as the world's longest-range commercial airliner. It first flew on 11 February 2002, and was certified on 3 December 2002. Air Canada was supposed to be the launch customer, but filed for bankruptcy in January 2003(...). This allowed early deliveries to the new launch customer, Emirates(...). The A340-500 can fly 313 passengers in a three-class cabin layout over 16020 km (8650 nm).(...) The A340-500 is powered by four 240 kN (54,000 lbf) thrust Rolls-Royce Trent 553 turbofans(...). It was the world's longest-range commercial airliner until the introduction of its direct rival, Boeing 777-200LR, in February 2006."

-Wikipedia

This model is roughly 1/100 scale designed to be printed in a printer with an 8x8x8in print volume.

This model has intentionally tight tolerances and will likely require sanding to fit properly.

comments.text: Sorry to bug you again but should I use supports for the body parts? Kind of on the edge right now because my bridging isn't perfect yet.
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: If you aren't confident in your bridging then use supports.
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Thanks alot for the input. One more question how much filament should this whole thing take up?
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Another issue I have just noticed is that the engines don't seem to lie flat on the build plate. The back half seems to be in the air.
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Th nacelles are a bit slanted, as is staged earlier this will require some support in order to print. During the design I worked on minimizing the part count rather than minimizing the need for support structure.
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Also how much filament overall?
comments.author: RTicknor

comments.text: I think it was around 800 grams, I don't remember exactly and don't have the model with me to weigh right now
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Also in what orientation should I print the parts? I want to try and make sure that I have no failed parts with this project. =D
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Generally print parts with the flat sides down. For the winds this mean the root cords down and for the engines with the front down.
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Should I print this with or without supports?
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: I printed with support for 20 to 30 degree overhangs
comments.author: jakexie6

comments.text: Hi R Ticknor,
comments.author: Thomaseddm

comments.text: I added new files, all of them sliced fine in Simplify3d V4
comments.author: Thomaseddm

comments.text: Thank you soooo much for your fast respond!
comments.author: RTicknor

comments.text: Body part 3 is corrupt. I have 99% of the plane done and need body [part 3 to be reset or redone.
comments.author: DaveMister

comments.text: I just uploaded a body part 3 v2 that should fix your issues. It sliced fine on Z-suite, cura, and simplify 3D
comments.author: DaveMister

comments.text: Total print time on prusa i3 approx?
comments.author: Reidyy123

comments.text: I used a Zortrax M200 with 0.09mm layer resolution, normal resolution, and low infill. Total print time was a bit under 100h.
comments.author: Reidyy123

comments.text: What software did you use to make this??
comments.author: FrankieB

comments.text: I used Blender and drawings from https://www.the-blueprints.com/ to make the model. Additionally NetFabb was used to repair a few parts here and there.
comments.author: FrankieB

comments.text: is it possible to have high quality model and not low poly?
comments.author: RTicknor

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: paoloboni

comments.text: UAU!

description.text:
Wall mount for the HTC Vive HMD. I saw some wall mounts on here but I wasn't comfortable with suspending the headset from inside (near the lenses) so I designed this. The headset rests on the edges, is easy to remove quickly, and the lenses face towards the ground to protect against sun glare.

title: Compact 40 Watt 4,000 Lumen LED Shop Light

description.text:
This is a super powerful and compact 40-watt shop plight. It can light up my entire street like day! This small device is capable of cranking out a crazy 4,000 lumens! This shop is about to get lit :) The assembly video listed below includes links to all the parts and tools you will need to build it. A GoPro mount can be used to attach any GoPro handle, or you can use one of our own custom handles. A 26mm external diameter acrylic rod is used for our custom rod handle.

Assembly Tutorial:
https://youtu.be/lTiddPHAx8E

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I recommend that you use simplify 3D as a slicing program because their supports are super easy to get off and this design uses a lot of supports. Make sure to put all parts that have a raft .3mm off the raft, or the raft can be challenging to get off. If I don't mention a specific setting, just use your current setting.

MAIN BODY:
 -Print the body file with supports and a raft in PLA.

OTHER:
 -Print the front LED organiser in PLA with no supports or raft.
 -Print the back in PLA with no rafts or supports.

HANDLES:
 -Print the pistol grip handle with a raft and no supports.
 -Print the rod handle with supports and 100% infill

Step 1: Remove all supports

When you are done printing, there will be some supports on the mainframe/body and your rod handle extension. Carefully remove these supports with a pair of long nose pliers. If there are any other bits of bumpy/sharp pieces of plastic left on the outside of your mainframe/body make sure to remove them with your pliers.

Step 2: Assembly

Now that you have your 3D printed parts, you can move on to the next step of assembly. We have created a step by step tutorial video on youTube for you all to watch. We hope you all enjoy this project as much as we did!

Assembly Video

title: Reusable Filter for Drinkwell Original Pet Fountain

description.text:
The Drinkwell fountain includes a disposable filter that removes any bad tastes/odors and extracts debris from water, but replacing the filter every 2/3 weeks costs money and it's a pain having to periodically order new filters.This reusable filter uses regular activated carbon sold in pet shops to purify the water of aquariums. I bought 320 g of activated carbon for 6 Euros that allows to recharge 30 times the filter. According to the activated carbon manufacturer, 10g allows to purify 3 liters of water. You can use as filtering material stainless steel mesh screens or woven/non woven fabrics (depending on what is available for you).The filter can accomodate different material thicknesses.
Update june 15,2016: v2 higher activated carbon content and modified rubber band attachment

description.text: CC3D Mini Revolution mount
Endstop for CoreXY carriage

My name is Ryan Williams (National Board Certified Teacher and Milken Educator) and I designed these lessons to take students through the engineering process while taking advantage of my school’s 3D printer. These lessons are engaging for both male and female students because of the use of action figures/dolls and problem solving. Your students will take the reins of project based learning and engineering by coming up with a product for the action figure/doll. Writing and public speaking play a major role in this process too because students will be answering open-ended questions, creating a magazine advertisement and a television commercial. Your job as of an educator takes on the role of the facilitator of learning.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Software

My students and I use Tinkercad.com to design all of our models and then download the file to our Makerbot printer. The photo below is of a helicopter I designed for a lego figurine.

Project: Action Figure/Doll Challenge

Project Name: Action Figure/Doll Challenge

Overview & Background: Your students will take the reins of project based learning and engineering by coming up with a product for the action figure/doll. Your job as of an educator takes on the role of the facilitator of learning.

Objectives: Your students will be expected to engage with the 4 C's of PBL: communication, collaboration, creativity and critical thinking.

Audiences: Students in grades 3-6 would be ideal for this project.

Subjects: Math, Science, Engineering, Technology, Public Speaking and Creative Writing.

Skills Learned: Your students will learn to work in cooperative groups, think critically, engage in creative writing and communicate their findings and products with others.

Lesson/Activity: Download the worksheets that accompany this project. Assign students to Tinkercad.com. Students will need action figures/dolls-I would suggest bringing in their own because students will want to keep what they have made. Students should have product advertisements to look through and be able to access youtube to see various product commercials.

Duration: This project is designed to be a cross curricular assignment that could last anywhere from 5 to 10 days.

Preparation: Students should be familiar with the use of a ruler. Students should have a few days to explore the Tinkercad.com site.

References: N/A

Rubric & Assessment: I am not including a rubric with this project. BIE.org has several rubrics that can be modified to fit your assessment needs.

Handouts & Assets: The handouts were included when I uploaded the file.
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

they are leak proof as printed, (with the printer i used anyway) i mostly wanted to make the surface a little smoother and shinier.
To finish them I went over them with some sandpaper, (probably 80 grit, very briefly) to get rid of stray material and round the corners a bit. I took everything outside, poured some acetone into a medicine-cup container, held a printed pan with tweezers, dunked it in, immediately took it out, pour the excess back, and let the acetone evaporate off. the pan-shape did cause it to puddle inside a little bit, so the inside bottom got a little more exposure to it since of course that took longer to evaporate.
please note: i did minimal research on this, i've used acetone to take paint of plastics previously, so. .i was basically guessing. it worked out this time, but i do not advise skipping research, especially since there's youtube tutorials now.
comments.author: FavioR

description.text:
I think about reuse the octopus ball-jointing system for a quite long time. And I need something to scare my cat visiting my neighbour at my secondary residence because she's scared by cat. Hopefully I notice that may cat is scared by snake like object.... Got a solution, just need a snake head, Thingiverse is done for this!

The first cat's reaction seem to be "good".... Hope my neighbour isn't afraid by snake too!

The segment has been remade to improve a bit its flexibility.

Printer:

OverLord Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The scale I use for the tail is 228%, the biggest segment scale is 507%, the step I use for scale is 7%... I know I made some mistakes! The head scale is 520% make it easier the clip (not easy enough to avoid breaking the head connector... After breaking the tongue by awkwardness and tiredness). Many thanks to glue!

The Head

Making the head was quite difficult and there is some trouble as :

  • unwanted cavities (behind the eyes by example),
  • a too long neck (an be replaced by another segment),
  • not-separated tongue making it difficult to print, easy to break and not printable with another colour.
The Segments

Having a round (without the flat bottom) version would be nice. Having a nicer bottom is also possible.

The Tail

Making a version without bottom and without barrier around the ball would permit giving it many more positions can be nice too.

The Monster Option

Adding segment that permit making multi headed and/or multi tailed monster is also in my projects (don't hope it too soon).

comments.text: what should I do if I can't get the segments popped together
comments.author: Vizenre

comments.text: I suggest you print 2 segments and test them. If you have a trouble in assembling it, print another segment with a different scale and test it... Until you find the good scale step.
comments.author: Vizenre

comments.text: Are all the segments one size or are some of them slightly resized? If resized how does that effect them in attaching?
comments.author: sd_dreamcrystal

comments.text: I print the tail first (228% as I say in "print settings" section), I print segments larger and larger to ease the mounting (I try to use a 7% step between each segment but calculus after finishing the print show that I fail to keep it constant). I use the same trick (with a greater step) when I made a version of the Ball-jointed articulated octopus. The locking is still good. My regret is that it still scale up too fast and I should consider trying to print assembled segments (so without needing the scale trick).

Sanguine is the Daedric Prince of debauchery. He also has domain over the darker natures of man, such as lust, sin, sloth, gluttony, and greed. He is the patron deity of sinners and is often seen with a bottle of wine or beer (ale) in his hand. Sanguine enjoys playing pranks on others, one such example being a spell that removes the clothing of everyone within the spell's radius. Although a joker, Sanguine prefers to drag mortals down to sinful lifestyles by means of temptation and humiliation.

title: Y stage linear bearing holder for TOM

description.text: When changed over to linear bearings in my X stage carriage (Thing:14747) I wanted to do the same for my Y stage. I've designed this thing to replace the drive rib on the Y stage.

The holder was printed on a TOM with a MK6+ on a heated build platform. My settings were: Object infill% 35, Layer height(mm) .32, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 32 raft checked - full support.
The belt block settings were: Object infill% 100, Layer height(mm) .27, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 32 no raft - no support. I've designed this thing to replace the drive rib on the Y stage. Print both parts and clean up the mess on the holder, spend some time cleaning up the slots on the rib with an exacto. Press the bearings in until they are flush with edge of the protruding tabs, they don't get pressed in all the way, you want them protruding the stage sides (see photo). Use a rod from the Y stage to check the alignment of the bearings. The hardest part of this project is tearing apart the whole Y stage, lots of screws! Remove the rib and take the belt out. Replace the belt and use the bearing block and two 3X20mm countersink screws and nuts to pinch the belt on the holder. Reassemble the Y stage.

comments.text: I'm surprised this hasn't gotten any attention. Sure, a dab of hot glue has been holding the bearings in just fine, but every time I looked at it it just seemed so wrong. Thanks!
comments.author: dreameredeemer

comments.text: I just made a similar x stage linear bearing and I think in the photo I see a retainer ring on the linear bearing. I used them also, mainly to keep from pressing them in all the way. It could be that the retainer ring sits nicely on the inside behind the wood panel and keeps the bearing from wanting to come out. Mine were pretty tight and I don't think they are going anywhere.

title: Logitech c920 Webcam Mount for IKEA Tertial Lamp

description.text:
This is a mount for the Logitech c920 webcam. It attaches to the ever popular $8.99 USD IKEA Tertial Work Lamp. I like this more than a printer-mounted webcam solution because of the freedom the articulating arm allows. Also this design doesn't require you to modify the webcam in any other way, just thread the base with a traditional 1/4" tripod sized screw.

For installation, you'll reuse the screws from the lamp (the ones that mount to the shade) and a 1/4" standard tripod thread screw. Cut out the lamp fixture/cables and you're good to go! I use two of these lamps for my setup, one with an adjustable wifi light, the other with the webcam. Enjoy!

ALSO! If you don't know what to do with the left over lamp shade, why not convert it into a flower pot? Here's a link to the quick upcycle project I did with the extra lampshade! IKEA Lamp Shade - Flower Pot Conversion

comments.text: Tried to make this also. Snapped after I tried to move it around. Good start though!
comments.author: Jrkodysz

comments.text:
I made two attempts to use this as-is, but sadly it didn't work for me.
First, the hole was far too small for the screw to mount the camera - it had to be tightened with muscle and pliers. Second, the whole thing is far too thin and weak - attempting to screw in the camera AND attempting to screw it to the plate both ended up snapping the piece in half. Good idea, but it just isn't working for me in execution.

title: N Scale Matrix/Maze with textured terrain base

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4mNzCUbvivJ

Original version is 20mm tall, modified 7/7/16 and added a file with a 10mm tall version (file name with _1). The 1mm tall version is also slightly less wide, making it more compatible with an M3D.

This was also originally marked as HO scale. While the openings in the maze are just wide enough for an HO scale figure, the height, for a true towering or garden maze is more appropriate for an N scale figure. The openings between the walls then leave a bit more room for this figural figure to move about - if they could do that.

I used Inkscape and GIMP to process the original image source (in-game symbol of Azura). Then, I modelled the amulet in Blender.

Azura is the Daedric Prince of Dusk and Dawn, the magic between Day and Night. Her sister is Nocturnal. She is known to be one of the more merciful and benevolent Lords, though her wrath is swift and painful when it is brought about. She oversees the Daedric Realm of Moonshadow, a beautiful world of blurred colors, streaming together, cities of silver, and air like perfume. The ones who visit this realm are mostly of either the Dunmer of Morrowind or the Khajiit of Elsweyr as both revere Azura, though in different respects.
The mountains are a bit rough but this is a topography map of Westeros

Hermaeus Mora is the Daedric Prince of knowledge and memory; his sphere is the scrying of the tides of Fate, of the past and future as read in the stars and heavens. He is not known for being good or evil; he seems to be the keeper of both helpful and destructive knowledge.

Speaker enclosures suitable for 100mm diameter, 48mm deep speakers (although 43mm ones would probably be fine).

Mounting was accomplished with adhesive in my case; you could add holes or whatever you need.

There are two part files for each side, and two mirrored models.

description.text:
I bought a detached case for my Raspberry Pi V2 camera. This one: https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IJZJKK4/ and wanted to mount it on a CamRah tripod. This one: http://camrah.com/collections/frontpage/products/pro-series-flexible-tripod-with-jaws-phone-holder-and-bonus-bluetooth-shutter-remote

So I designed these in OpenSCAD.

The first mounts directly to the 1/4-20 tripod mounting screw using a square 1/4-20 nut. I used Bondic to secure my nut inside the mount adapter. Because my nut was very shiny I had to "rough it up" a bit to get the Bondic to stick. Gluing the nut inside the adapter isn't necessary for proper operation but it helps prevent losing the nut.

The second adapter is to use when you have a "cell phone" mount for your tripod. There are spring loaded adapters that clamp to the cell phone. This adapter works well in one of those.

I have included the source OpenSCAD files for those that wish to modify the design. Everybody should include their source file for their designs.

I'm using the camera as a HumCam and for other goodies.

Printer:

Micro3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Use a square 1/4-20 nut for the direct tripod adapter. Use M3 screws and nuts to attach the Pi camera case to the adapters.
The mount adapter is the blue part. Closeup

description.text:
I have an Ikea Linnamon table. I have lots of headphones, and I mean lots. Sometimes I like to switch but I only have 1 stand so I decided to make a holder, it's very basic but it comes with a screw to use on smaller tables. the widest opening is 34mm which is the size of the linnamon table top, The screw should clamp down something 2cm or thicker, it is just barely too small for my ikea pc desk hutch, that measures 19mm thick and it's a mill or 2 too thin. I could use paper to close the gap. If I get enough requests I will try to duplicate the screw threads to make a longer screw, this was my 1st attempt at it and luckily it worked.

Your printer will need to be calibrated pretty good for this to print right, the 1st time i inserted the screw the threads were a bit tight but now it works awesome.

title: The Coiler [motor version] (for clapton, juggernaut and twisted coils) - Vape Mod

description.text:
This is the final version of The Coiler (i hope !).
After belt edition (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1611185) and the gear edition (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1613771) i decide to develope a motor version using a 12v motor with gear reduction.

With this u can do:

  • a classic clapton coil;
  • a juggernaut coil;
  • a twister coil (using on the right side the wire_gear_dx_for_twisting.stl).

About the print STL named with _x2 final u have to print double.

To mount u need:

  • some self-tapping A2 DIN7982 screw 3.5x16 (these are very standard !) to assembly the frame;
  • 2x M3x15 (with nuts) for crankshaft;
  • 2x M3x10 for wire fixing;
  • 1x M3x15 for knob mounting;
  • 1x M3x10 headless screw for motor gear;
  • 2x M1.6x6 or M1.6x8 to fixing the motor;

About the circuit i chosed the PMW TE234.
The motor is called 12GAN20 and there're two kind: 100 and 300 RPM.
Probably with the PWM the 300 RPM is the best way.
About circuit and motor some hopefull link:

  • motor 100 rpm http://fave.co/2boGGIX or http://fave.co/2bsiyZ4
  • motor 300 rpm http://fave.co/2boI4Lq or http://fave.co/2boH5uR
  • pwm http://fave.co/2boGYPP

Update 27/06/2016 - Released

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGfgZTaDbOk

Update 09/07/2016
Added vertical_panel_sx_big_motor.stl and motor_gear_big.stl.
This new two parts work with another king of motor.
This one http://fave.co/2bsj89v or this one http://fave.co/2boH8a4

To fix it u need 4x M3x10-12 mm.
The other parts are the same.

Update 18/07/2016
Added:

  • big_circuit_box_cover.stl
  • big_circuit_box.stl
    This version of circuit box is for another king of circuit.
    This version is biggest then other, it cost the same, and it's called "PWM DC 6V 12V 24V 28V 3A Motor Speed Control Switch Controller".
    U fint it on ebay or amazon.
    One link http://fave.co/2bsjEUA or http://fave.co/2boH9eg

title: Paint Bottle Holder for Paint Shaker

description.text:
This is a pretty niche product; I tend to get hand me down paints and purchase used sets off ebay so I ended up getting one of these mixers instead of relying on elbow grease...

These two assemblies are made to replace the strap on the Robart Manufacturing Paint Shaker.

Works with short GW (old hex/black top and newer) and tall Vallejo, Army Painter bottles.; just slide the insert for the taller bottles (see image). Depending on paint amount you can put two short GW paint bottles on the left and right of the assembly and it will still shake them up without too much strain on the motor - just be sure your lids click shut completely otherwise you'll get a bit of a mess. It can hold older GW hex/black topped and wider P3 paint bottles upright but you'll have to keep a light finger-hold on the top of the bottle as it shakes.

Depending on tolerance you may want to adhere some painters or gaffers tape on the inside of the taller bottle assembly to allow for variations in diameter of paint bottles to fit snuggly enough so as not to shake out but still easy enough to remove...

author: b0235g10d

description.text:
I used Inkscape and GIMP to process the original image source (in-game symbol of Fen'Harel). Then, I modelled the amulet in Blender.

Fen'Harel, the elven god of betrayal (or god of rebellion) is also known as the Dread Wolf, He Who Hunts Alone, Lord of Tricksters, The Great Wolf, Roamer of the Beyond, the old wolf, and Bringer of Nightmares. He was known as kin to both the Creators and the Forgotten Ones. His supposed betrayal of both clans of gods by sealing them away in their respective realms, never again to interact with the mortal world, is sometimes used to explain why the elven gods did not intervene to prevent the fall of Arlathan. Indeed, Fen'Harel has allegedly never been fond of the elven people and is said to have spent centuries in a far corner of the earth after his great deception, hugging himself and giggling madly in glee.

title: Calibrate your printer x,y,z and e quickly and easily.

description.text:
UPDATED V3 added - same as V2 except I have included a pair of towers and a bridge, this should test retraction settings as strings will form between the towers if your retraction is insufficient, bridge is a test of part cooling fan's ability to cool the filament enough to keep it horizontal.

UPDATED V2 added. So a few tweaks, I've made the 50mm x50mm part a little taller as use of brims, and the spread of filament on the first layer make measuring without a little extra height more difficult and less accurate, so measure from just above the first layer for x and y. I've included straight and rotated (for corexy) versions.

Okay so we've all come across Triffid Hunter's Guide (http://reprap.org/wiki/Triffid_Hunter's_Calibration_Guide) and in it he suggests using 5mm calibration cube steps (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24238) which is a very useful model. However I wanted something a little more accurate and able to do esteps fine tuning more easily.

So this object can be used for x and y calibration. Its 50mm x 50mm so larger and more accurate for adjusting x and y steps/mm than the typical 20mmx20mm cube. Z is only 10mm in the standard version to make it quicker to print, but I have included a version with a tower to 25mm for z calibration also, slightly too tall or too short might also help indicate under/over extrusion.

The next part is e-steps. Triffid Hunter's guide recommends printing an object with 95% infill and adjusting esteps or flow on the fly to the point where little gaps appear between infill lines. This however only sets one end of the fine tuning range for esteps. At the other end is the point at which infill becomes stringy.

Set infill in your slicer to 15% rectilinear so it can easily be seen. Then using Slic3r (other slicers might do this differently) "split" the model. The smaller cube can then be assigned custom parameters (right click and pick settings for the smaller cube) assign infill_density 95%.

Now print it, one cube will print lightly infilled so you can easily see if the infill is stringy and increase flow/esteps the other will print dense, but not complete, infill so you can reduce esteps/flow if you cannot see tiny gaps between infill lines. In this way you arrive at the mid point between slightly-under and slightly-over extruding. As per Triffid Hunter's guide don't start adjusting until you get to layer 5 or 6 as the amount of squash on your first layer affects the layer height too much until that point. A good point to begin to adjust the flow/esteps is once the outer 50x50mm wall has finished and the printer is just printing the two cubes, this is around z=3mm.

I have also included a set of thin walls. They are 0.3mm, 0.4mm, 0.5mm and 0.6mm. Slic3r prints these all at 0.4mm with my 0.4mm nozzle but gaps in these walls indicates slight under-extrusion, unless you hear some pops as they print then this is either gas escaping from the nozzle most likely water vapour, dry your filament out if this happens, or the temperature is too high and the filament is breaking down producing gas, lower the nozzle temp.

The A and B markings are for corexy printers, the model is rotated 45 deg so belt tension can be differentially adjusted (this can be avoided if you are using a balanced belt tension carriage like this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1582049 and your two corexy belts are exactly equal in length). I have written a guide to easily adjusting x versus y here on reprap (http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?344,705441,705441#msg-705441) or use this guide if it makes more sense to you http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?397,530210 for adjustment of the belts.

The version with the z tower only requires around 6.5g of plastic (ABS) and takes around 50 minutes to print at 50mm/s avg print speed.

description.text: The idea is that you can mount this with double sided adhesive to whatever surface you want using the four feet on the underside. Using it is pretty simple. You just grab your filter and begin to open it so you can slide it onto the tip of the cone, then just keep going until it's pressed all the way on. It's a perfect fit with the inside of the filter, so at this point the seam has been parted perfectly, and all that's left to do is bend the seam to the side and transfer the filter to your V60. It's a bit overkill, but I'm very anal about my V60 filters being folded just right.

Try #3, trying to avoid a fill on the big rectangle.
This didn't render correctly on the Thingiverse site, and Firefox 3 doesn't handle the text area quite right either.  However, it did import into Corel Draw, although we had to fix the sign part.  I'm going to try to fix the file a little more and reupload.

When assembling the plane, you need to use a little emory board or sandpaper on the tabs of the wings to get them to fit into place.  The fit is just too tight fresh off the cutter.  The stands worked fine.

title: Super Mario Question Mark Block Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: It's a real-world question mark block! Will it contain coins or a power up? Ok, well, neither actually - just some custom electronics designed to make the bottom capacitive-touch sensitive. When you punch - er, touch - the bottom, the light toggles on and off and plays the classic "coin" noise. Once in while, though, you might find that you get something... extra. Check out this video of the lamp in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J05lAg8_1zY I designed this in OpenSCAD and cut it out of several colors of acrylic. I'm going to post the scad file as well as the Eagle PCB design and the firmware once I have cleaned those up a little. In the meantime, if you must have one, you can buy a kit from our Etsy store: http://www.etsy.com/listing/90652319/super-mario-inspired-touch-sensitive

I used Inkscape and GIMP to process the original image source (in-game symbol of Sheogorath). Then, I modelled the amulet in Blender.

Sheogorath is the Daedric Prince of Madness. His realm in Oblivion is known as the Shivering Isles, otherwise known as the Madhouse, or "The Asylums" by the Imperial Census of Daedra Lords. It is separated into two communities: Mania, the fantastic, colorful side, where art enthusiasts and insane revelers reside, and Dementia, the horrific, dark and ominous side, inhabited by those with the darker side of Sheogorath's blessings. Sheogorath is attended by his Chamberlin Haskill and the Nobles of his realm, the Duke and Duchess of Mania and Dementia.
Une Nodkoko pour Moon ou Kanniboul Thierry
Nodkoko en Wood pour Moon

I bought a dashcam because the drivers around me are cuckoo bananas. There weren't any easy places to mount it, and I ended up settling with where I put it. Enter a 3d printer. I made this after some quick measurements to basically take the part that connects to the camera, remove the articulating ball, and use an adhesive strip to mount it to a piece of plastic behind my mirror. Printing it right now, we'll see how it goes. 'Til then, here it is! There will be updates!

It works! But there can be improvements. The rounded part could be shorter to allow for a greater range of motion, the cutout for the bolt to go through needs to be a bit bigger (I need to get a digital caliper to measure stuff, no bones about it), and there could be a similar mechanism to allow it to lock into place instead of being a snug fit.

But hey, IT WORKS!

UPDATE

It worked for a bit. I didn't print it solid, and I didn't print it in ABS. The plastic started sagging and the command strip adhesive didn't hold up to closed-car-level temperatures. Back to the drawing board!
